currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way.

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

Screen time during the pandemic was on the rise simply because we all were stuck at home. There wasn't much to do. Screens probably kept us from going insane. Imagine being stuck at home and not being able to use the internet or watch television? What would people who liv

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

Screen time during the pandemic was on the rise simply because we all were stuck at home. There wasn't much to do. Screens probably kept us from going insane. Imagine being stuck at home and not being able to use the internet or watch television. What would people who live alone do? Stare at a wall?

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

Screen time during the pandemic was on the rise simply because we all were stuck at home. There wasn't much to do. Screens probably kept us from going insane. Imagine being stuck at home and not being able to use the internet or watch television. What would people who live alone do? Stare at a wall?

Screen time is beneficial to humans. It allows us to have basically any information at our fingertips. It allows us to relax and wind down. It allows us to keep our mind off the problems and issues that we face on a daily basis. It also allows us to keep in contact with our family and friends via FaceTime

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

Screen time during the pandemic was on the rise simply because we all were stuck at home. There wasn't much to do. Screens probably kept us from going insane. Imagine being stuck at home and not being able to use the internet or watch television. What would people who live alone do? Stare at a wall?

Screen time is beneficial to humans. It allows us to have basically any information at our fingertips. It allows us to relax and wind down. It allows us to keep our mind off the problems and issues that we face on a daily basis. It also allows us to keep in contact with our family and friends via FaceTime and texting. 

In general I believe that screen

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

Screen time during the pandemic was on the rise simply because we all were stuck at home. There wasn't much to do. Screens probably kept us from going insane. Imagine being stuck at home and not being able to use the internet or watch television. What would people who live alone do? Stare at a wall?

Screen time is beneficial to humans. It allows us to have basically any information at our fingertips. It allows us to relax and wind down. It allows us to keep our mind off the problems and issues that we face on a daily basis. It also allows us to keep in contact with our family and friends via FaceTime and texting. 

In general I believe that screen time isn't a real issue for most

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

Screen time during the pandemic was on the rise simply because we all were stuck at home. There wasn't much to do. Screens probably kept us from going insane. Imagine being stuck at home and not being able to use the internet or watch television. What would people who live alone do? Stare at a wall?

Screen time is beneficial to humans. It allows us to have basically any information at our fingertips. It allows us to relax and wind down. It allows us to keep our mind off the problems and issues that we face on a daily basis. It also allows us to keep in contact with our family and friends via FaceTime and texting. 

In general I believe that screen time isn't a real issue for most of the population. As long as you keep it in moderation and it isn

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

Screen time during the pandemic was on the rise simply because we all were stuck at home. There wasn't much to do. Screens probably kept us from going insane. Imagine being stuck at home and not being able to use the internet or watch television. What would people who live alone do? Stare at a wall?

Screen time is beneficial to humans. It allows us to have basically any information at our fingertips. It allows us to relax and wind down. It allows us to keep our mind off the problems and issues that we face on a daily basis. It also allows us to keep in contact with our family and friends via FaceTime and texting. 

In general I believe that screen time isn't a real issue for most of the population. As long as you keep it in moderation and it isn't affecting your phys

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, there are many potential downsides and benefits to the constant use of our devices, depending on their content, context and purpose. For example, it’s been linked to low social competence in younger kids, as a distraction from family bonding, and a risk factor for obesity. However screen time also allows for younger kids to learn new things by using apps and using the internet. 

Screen time simply needs to be used in moderation. Social media is very similar. There are pros and cons to everything but when you overuse something it becomes a negative. There’s a reason that if you overuse coffee, it’ll make you feel anxious and irritable. A cell phone or a tablet can work the same way. It also can damage your eyes.

It allows us to keep our mind off the problems and issues that we face on a daily basis. It also allows us to keep in contact with our family and friends via FaceTime and texting. 

In general I believe that screen time isn't a real issue for most of the population. As long as you keep it in moderation and it isn't affecting your physical or mental well being, do what you enjoy
